subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Newsletter
msgSnippet: There isn t an official QS mapping in Unicode but there is an area in the official mapping which is reserved for private use (the PUA). Oliver has helpfully
messageBody:
There isn't an official QS mapping in Unicode but there is an area in
the official mapping which is reserved for private use (the PUA).
Oliver has helpfully created an experimental mapping in that area.

You can get Read Schoolbook from http://slate.langan.net/readunicode/.
Also Kingsley.ttf, another Unicode font, can be found in the fonts
folder in the files section (there is an ASCII font with the same name,
installing both at the same time may cause problems in certain
circumstances).

There are problems with mappings in the PUA,
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U+F8FF is a good example of the code clash
issue, but for most people it should just work.
We really should try and get a proposal for an official mapping, I'll
have another peek at the request process, last time I looked the number
of pages scared me off. :(


pgabhart wrote:
>
> amd64:
>
> I didn't mean to get carried away with the "properly setup" phrase. I
> am pretty much self-taught regarding computers. I tell people I am
> semi-computer literate. :-)
>
> Your e-mail just made me think of lots more questions. As an example,
> I have questions about Unicode. I think I have a rudimentary
> understanding of what it is and its purpose. We have talked about
> getting QS included in unicode. but that hasn't happened yet so I
> don't understand how you can have a "Unicode test." of QS alphabets.
> What does that mean? You make a reference to Unicode QS fonts. What
> does that mean? Hopefully, I am not the only one in the group so
> dismally ignorant about this. If you can take a little time to
> explain some of this, maybe others will benefit besides me.
>
> If I open Oliver's QS_unicode_sample.txt in the font section of
> Read_Alphabet (RA), I get the same series of "?????" that I got with
> your test. What is "Read Schoolbook." Presumably, it is a QS font,
> but I tried a Google search and did not find any reference to it.
> Where did you find it?
>
> Paige
>
> amd64_hacker wrote:
>
>> 'Properly setup' was probably not the best phrase to use, I meant a
>> machine which has a good selection of Quikscript fonts (both ascii and
>> Unicode) and full Unicode support.
>>
>> The fonts for the Unicode test were Read Schoolbook and Kingsley.
>> The ascii test used king plus, jerome, kingsley, kwikskript and QSJ
>> Block.
>>
>> I forgot to ask if there are there any other fonts which should be added
>> in my previous email.
>>
>> Also which OS/Browser are you using?
>> We can try to change the tests to make that combo work and if we find
>> that we can't make it work then we know not to use that method.
>>
>> I was treating ascii as an abbreviation, taking each letter from the
>> first letter of the full word.
>> The manual says to use naming dots before each letter but I couldn't
>> seem to find the naming dot in the mapping so I did without.
>> How do you type a naming dot?
>>
>> The first letter of American should probably have be 'at' rather than
>> 'utter', my excuse is that I do actually say Uh-merica sometimes. :)
>>
>> I was thinking about vowels as I was walking home today, in particular I
>> realised I have no idea how to pronounce Unicode.
>> When I say it I say 'yoon' - 'ee' - 'code', but 'eh', 'ih' and 'ah'
>> don't sound that wrong.
>> In the end I opted to go with 'ih' which seemed the most 'correct' to me.
>> I've got a few odd looks from passers by as I was testing those
>> combinations out. :)
>>
>> pgabhart wrote:
>> >
>> > amd64_hacker:
>> >
>> > I downloaded the test file to my Firefox browser. Only the ASCII test
>> > was correct. The other two consisted of a series of "?"s. You
>> > mentioned that a "properly set up computer" should display all three
>> > tests properly. What is your definition of a "properly set up
>> > computer"? Do you think if my computer was "properly set up" it would
>> > display the first and second tests correctly?
>> >
>> > When I copied the third tests and pasted it into Word Perfect, as long
>> > as the font was set to "Kingsley," it displayed correctly.
>> >
>> > Regarding spelling: I have always heard "ASCII" pronounced as "Askey".
>> > What you wrote I would transliterate as "uski (last letter short-i,
>> > rather than a long e sound.).
>> >
>> > Thanks for the test.
>> >
>> > Paige
>> >
>> > amd64_hacker wrote:
>> > >
>> > > I had further thoughts on point 1, I realise that 'it works for me'
>> > > probably wasn't the most helpful comment.
>> > > I've created a page which tests three methods of displaying QS
>> text in a
>> > > browser.
>> > >
>> > > The methods are:
>> > > Unicode + Font hints.
>> > > Unicode on it's own.
>> > > ASCII + Font hints.
>> > >
>> > > The first is the best compromise, the text is Unicode but we tell the
>> > > browser which font to use which solves the collision problem.
>> > > The second is the 'correct' method since it doesn't require
>> particular
>> > > fonts to be installed or special mark up but it's also the most
>> likely
>> > > to fail due to code point collisions in the PUA. :(
>> > > The third method should display correctly in just about any
>> browser but
>> > > if you copy the text you'll get the underlying ascii/latin text.
>> > >
>> > > Ideally all three tests should display the same text on a
>> properly setup
>> > > computer.
>> > > In the real world if we can find a method which works for most people
>> > > then we use that to talk to each other.
>> > >
>> > > I'd like to apologise for the spelling on the page, my ability to
>> write
>> > > in QS is not very good yet.
>> > >
>> > > I've uploaded the test page to the Fonts folder, please let me
>> know if
>> > > you have any ideas/suggestions/improvements.
>> > >
>> > >
>> >
>> >
>>
>
>

You can get Read Schoolbook from http://slate.langan.net/readunicode/.
